h1.a: Pseudo-Ptolemy, Dixerunt Ptolemeus et Hermes quod locus Lune in hora …

aside.p: Jean-Patrice Boudet, ‘Transcription of Pseudo-Ptolemy, Dixerunt Ptolemeus et Hermes quod locus Lune in hora …’ (update 28.05.2021), Ptolemaeus Arabus et Latinus. Texts, URL = https://ptolemaeus.badw.de/text/M667

div.p: In the manuscript tradition of the Centiloquium – both in translation attributed to Plato of Tivoli and in the ‘Mundanorum’ version –, this chapter on the rectification of nativities, together with a chapter on comets, generally appears at the beginning or end of the Centiloquium rather than in its logical place, after verbum 51. But this is precisely not the case in two of the most important manuscripts preserving the ‘Mundanorum’ version: Paris, BnF, lat. 16204, pp. 553a-584b, and London, BL, Sloane 2030, f. 11r-30r. This semi-critical edition is based on MS Florence, BR, 163 (F), with the variants from the following MSS noted in footnotes: Vatican, BAV, Vat. lat. 7616 (V); Paris, BnF, lat. 16204 (A); London, BL, Sloane 2030 (C); Madrid, BN, 10015 (M); Paris, BnF, lat. 7307 (P); Berlin, SBPK, Hamilton 557 (Be); and Paris, BnF, lat. 7413 (Pa).
